Design: Eliminate the meeting with Muskoka Kitchens and other manufacturers. Customer should be dealing with Tamarack only. Provide complete information regarding the products, i.e. the fact that what the customer will get may not match exactly what is in the design room. Take into account the personal needs and tastes of the client. Do not take it for granted that any customer should or will adopt the tastes and needs of the majority of the customers. Prices of standard products should be substracted from the price of the upgrades, or if you want to charge full price for upgrades, put the standard products in a box and give them to the customer. Hire more design consultants.

Sales: Explain exactly what 'structural' means to Tamarack so that the customer knows what has to be finalized with Sales. take the time to uinderstand what the customer needs to be sure if it should be dealt with at sales stage or at design.

Construction: That is the worst stage and really needs significant improvements. Hire more site supervisors. Hire more competent contractors. Give priority to people with values, who get self satisfaction with a job well done (the behaviour of some is near to vandalism. They do not care of the dirt or of the work done by the precedent contractor). Give importance to brieffing the contractors of the particulars of each home. Ensure that they read the paper work and sketches established at sales and Design stages. Ensure things are done properly from the outset (too much things are done sloppy and left to be corrected later. The final result looks like a rush job, a do-it-yourself instead of a professional work). It is the site inspectors job to ensure that the work of the contractors is coordinated and well done.

Overall everything to date has been terrific.  We absolutely love dealing with Jacqui Collier (Woodhaven in Kingston, ON).  She answers our questions promptly and accurately, she always returns our calls immediately and she is honest with us.  Jacqui's skills and personality  are what sold us on a Tamarack Home.  We had been to several other builders in the Kingston area and nobody has representation like Tamarack does with Jacqui.  As first time homebuyers it was important to us to feel we could trust the builder.  We didn't get a trustworthy feeling from any other builder (new homes) or even when we briefly looked at resale with realtors in Kingston.  Jacqui is the reason why we bought a Tamarack home.

Walk-Through:
I wasn't aware that we could note deficiencies in the Walk-Through process with the site super.  If I knew that I was supposed to be looking for deficiencies, I might have taken a closer look or pointed a couple of things out.  We still enjoyed our walk through with Mike.  he is extremely knowledgeable and was very friendly with us.  We are glad to know that someone with Mike's experience and perosnality is overseeing the construction of our first home.  

It was great to learn that Mike and Jacqui both own their own Tamarack homes as well.  This made me trust Tamarack even more.

Interiors:
The interiors selection process was a little bit overwhelming at times.  Granted there are a lot of decisions to be made, we felt that the process was a bit disorganized.  We would have liked to know how much various options cost as an input into our selections.  For example, it would have been more efficient when choosing our countertops to compare various options with respect to cost. Since we already know the counter in our model home is 'x' square feet, it is likely possible to provide us with an approximate cost per square foot for 'y' style marble with 'z' style of edge?  Going back and forth for quotes and comparing what was available in the show room vs. in vendor's storefronts was a bit painful.

We were also a bit unclear about the process for purchasing faucets and sinks.  We went to a local store which we thought was the supplier to Tamarack (just like we went to the tile store for tile/flooring and the counter store for granite).  After several visits to the faucets/sink store and requesting quotes on products, we learned that they were not the Tamarack supplier and the cost of buying the exact same faucets/sinks were higher through Tamarack due to shipping costs.  This was a bit disappointing because we could have just bought the exact same faucet and sinks for much cheaper (almost half price) a few blocks from our new house.

We had a bit of an issue with our hardwood price.  Tamarack forgot that we had selected hardwood for the hallway in our second floor.  They realized this with only a couple of days left to finalize our interiors which really impacted our budget.  At the last minute we had to cancel other interior selections which we had already spent hours deciding upon.  A bit frustrating, but we consider ourselves reasonable people and got over it.

We were a bit surprised when we received our initial kitchen drawings back from Muskoka.  They forgot about an 18” by  10” (approx.) wall that sticks out from the back-centre of our house into the kitchen (a supporting wall that separates the kitchen from the family room).  It wasn’t until I pointed this out to Tamarack that the mistake was caught and fixed.  Good thing we caught this otherwise we would have had only a foot and a couple of inches of clearance to walk between that wall and our kitchen island.

As mentioned above, our overall experience has been great.  Any time we have had any issues, unanswered questions, etc. Jacqui has been there to reassure us.  She was and will continue to be the reason why we chose Tamarack.

At first, I did not wish to bother you with these thoughts as often in large companies, one can only wounder who pays attention to these comments.  But this story need to be told as I am still offended about the service I received at the time of purchase, a year ago.

Let me explain.

I would definitely change the initial purchase phase.  It must be said that I was the tenth person in line for the second phase of the Tamarack Series.  This being said, I began 'camping' on the step of the sales office in the early hours of the Wednesday morning with several other enthusiastic buyers.  By 7pm that evening, the office had decided to give out priority numbers as they did not want any of their costumers to sleep on their porch.  This being said, I was the tenth person in line, therefore, secured number ten, or yet again, secured my name on the bungalow-towns purchase list.  I was then advise to return on the Friday morning as the purchases would begin at 10am.

Never the less, As I returned to the sales office at approx. 8am on Friday morning, I noticed that approx. 60 individuals had also attended the Office in an attempt to purchase a house.  Then to my great surprise, I was told to wait for several hours as the Office decided to sale the lots by way of reservation and not by way of priority.  They began deciding to sale the large single lots first, moved into the bungalows, then semis and so on, selling the units by category.  This truly and still insulted me as I lost my tenth position in line, thinking that I would be the tenth person to secure a lot. 

By the Friday, I had decided that I wanted to purchase a semi detach bungalow instead of of a town but as the sale office did not respect the priority numbers, I was only left with the bungalow town and never had the opportunity to purchase the lot that I wanted.  Further more, that morning, as my frustration grew towards the situation, I decided to enquirer about the priority numbers at the office, when I heard the sales person indicate that they are no longer calling individuals as they had 'lost control' of the situation and stated:'just get me four other person, anyone'.  Thankfully, I was beside them when one stated this as I immediately advised them of my frustration and that I would now be one of the four 'next' purchasers.  Even with these actions, I could not pick the initial lot that I wanted, after getting in line three days earlier and obtaining a number as I counted 22 dots of the site map.  First come, first serve is very important to me and it was disgustingly not the case during the purchase time.

I was very close to leaving the site that morning refusing to buy from your company.

Further more, at the sale center, I do have to mention that we were pressured by time.  Thankfully we had attended the center multiple times prior to our appointments but did not like being pushed out of our appointment because it took more time then the time allowed.  At the end we are purchasing a 300 000$ property and would like to be treated with respect as customers.

In conclusion, I am so far satisfied with the product but the service and the ultimate frustration at the time of purchase are still in my thoughts.

Thank you for your time
Respecfuly

Have clearer answers about possible changes to the home. We understand that it may take time to consult with the builders but it should not have taken months - literally - to answer some of our questions.

-- More clear communication from the ladies in the sales centre on the following: 
- We were told that our townhome had a rough-in for a washroom in the basement by the ladies in the sales centre. At our frame check, we were informed that this was not true.
- When we put a hold on the lot, we were told that our outside brick colour would be light grey (because we weren't able to choose the colour). But we can see now that the colour is slightly different. 

-- We had a AWFUL experience at The Brick. We would highly recommend changing the contact person or changing the company that purchasers have to go through to use the appliance bonus. Luckily, Mandy Mason at the Design Centre addressed our concerns when we told her about them. If it weren't for her, we don't know how we would have enjoyed the process at all. 
- Some details with regard to the poor client service/experience we dealt with at the Brick (West Hunt Club) for our Bonus Program: 
- As we already told Mandy at our sign off at the Design Centre, the whole experience was stressful and unpleasant. Here are some specific examples:
- The biggest issue is that Andrew Main insisted that we must pay for all the appliances we purchase in full to secure them (saying it's the Brick's policy). The problem with this is that no other furniture or appliance store does this (usually it's a deposit and then cash on delivery or just prior to delivery). Also, he did not guarantee that we would get the appliances for the prices that we purchased them for (i.e. if the price of the appliances drop - he said 'he doesn't have to respect the lower price', and if an appliance gets discontinued - he said 'it would be our problem and we would need to select the replacement piece or another model which may be more in price').
- He also had a 'it's not my problem, it's yours' attitude and would say things that made us just not want to deal with him ever again. Like 'well I get the money from Tamarack either way so it's up to you to do what you want to do'. He also asked us to send him info over e-mail so he could prepare pricing for us for when we met ... Every time we went to see him, he had nothing prepared and we had to sit with him while he looked up the pricing for each piece (turning a 30 minute scheduled appointment into an hour and 15 minutes).
- When we first tried to contact Andrew at the beginning of September to just get the starting information, he did not return our voicemails (2) and e-mails. We ended up going in on the weekend and talking to his colleague who is a Rep. for other builders and she nicely walked us through the appliance section and gave us the basic info she knew about. She left a note for Andrew on his desk since he hadn't gotten back to us and he ended up getting back to us a week later...When we first met him, he told us he didn't have much information for us besides the fact that the basic package was pretty low-end so he recommended opting for the bonus amount. But he said it was our responsibility to research the appliances and just send him the product codes (which was opposite to what the ladies at the Sales Center said - we were told he would help guide us).
- Another major issue we have is scheduling. He only works Monday to Friday from 8-4p.m. (with no flexibility) so we had to rush over on our lunch breaks or right after work to get time with him. Most client based places (like the Design Centre) have a few other evening or weekend options.

-- In all honestly, besides the time that we had to deal with Andrew Main, we have enjoyed the process so far. We also REALLY want to highlight how AMAZING Mandy Mason was with us. So helpful, kind, informative - and she's the one that corrected the whole issue with The Brick (especially because we weren't her only clients experiencing the same issues with him). Carla Mason has been very helpful as well - so prompt at getting back to us when we need confirmation of information as we approach our closing date.
Free items such as a coffee maker or vacuum or tv...

Two things:

1. We became aware at a late stage that we could have negotiated the design centre bonus of 5K to 10k which Tamarack had previously offered, so if we could, we would re-negotiate that. 

2. We would also re-negotiate the 10k lot premium. Looking at the thin line of trees in the back of the lot where our home is being build, we feel the 10k premiums is too high for what we are getting (we were expecting more privacy and more lush trees in the back).

-We would like to have the information available in both official languages of Canada.  It will be ideal to have in each sale centre at least one bilingual person.

-Increase the amount of money for ugrades.

We had an amazing experience from the sales and design centers. I personally found it a little hard to visualize the upgrade options, and wished a computerized display was available, if even just the big things like floor and cabinets. The staff is so knowledgeable and helpful, it did make it easier.

I'm happy with the services provided by the sales rep and the design centre 
They are all very understanding and cooperative and are ready to understand and help whenever required . 

 Thank you tamarack for being a great builder.
To be told you have to go to all the different stores to pick out your finishes. We thought we could do more of that at the model home. Just being informed of that would have been nice.

We were very happy with the sales process, however it would be great if the design centre would be able to be more clear with the options available, including pricing, and to have options for visualising the house with the upgrades chosen eg. a computer program. We were given a price list that had inaccurate information, and because of that and our time constraint we didn't do some upgrades we had been discussing. However, we are so far (without seeing the house yet!) happy with the design choices we made and we did not feel pressured to choose something we didn't want.
More time at the design centre and provided with more information regarding upgrades.
Happy with both.
Nothing!

Advertising fake-Indicates many upgrades. Standard choices are horrible so need to upgrade almost everything.  You offered $5000.00 sign-on bonus but then you took $500.00 tax.  Be upfront about reality you offer $5000-you suck up the tax. You over charge so so much.  To me the upgrades are a money grab.  $500 for an upgraded sink faucet when the company price was $250.00 is ludicrous.  The trades are 'pigs' cups, pop cans in the walls & my new tubs (keep covers over the tubs) A mess!
Refer to question:
1. Properly greeted me when I entered the office: a bit elitist.
3.  Coffee cups in walls, lots of saw dust, tradesperson smoking in my home (while installing insulation)  The siding already falling off the house.

Just some minor inconveniences:
- The Design Centre was not always aware of some upgrades no longer being available.  So we would make our selections, then had to go back to the Design centre and select another upgrade.
- The Design Centre was not always aware of some upgrades being compatable with other upgrades. For example, an upgraded sink was not campatable with an upgraded faucet. Again we would have to return to the Design Centre to choose another upgrade.

1. I think that final costs of all upgrades etc should be provided in advance of the final sign off meeting. Had i had these costs in advance, I would have made additional upgrades, unfortunately at 8pm on the night of  my sign of meeting i was presented with the costing and only then realized i had a lot more room for upgrades etc. but by then it was too late.

A one-page, summarized milestone checklist to guide the buyer through the purchase process, that they receive before hand.
Also, clearer documentation (final summary of all upgrades agreed to with total cost) promptly provided, rather than handwriting on the purchase summary.
Online selection

Informing clients that they should come in before their scheduled appointments at the design centre to browse (we went in on our own simply for our own piece of mind...we were told that we didn't need to until our appointment, but the extra browing time definitely helped us feel more confident with our options).

We are disappointed that we are not giving credits when not taking standard options. i.e. We do not want the mantle, surround or hearth for the upstairs fireplace and are being given a credit for that cost. Overall, the Tamarack experience has been very good so far.

Sales centre : the upgrades included in model homes should have a price associated to them on the specifications sheet. The upgrades done in the model homes are not always obvious based on the description of the specification sheet. 

Design centre : We would have liked to have more time to get advice from the consultant on design choices.(additional meeting might have been good)

Frame check : we have identified some deficiencies in the home but the site supervisor did not provide us with the opportunity to see if the deficiencies were repaired in the home.(the foam sheets had huge cracks between them or holes, some ducks were folded shut or flasher tape was cut through, the water line coming inside the home did not seem secure. We had some questions for the site supervisor and he is presently not returning my calls. Also, the available hours to have the frame check done were not convenient for us (mornings only).

Communication! It seemed that no one was on the same page regarding timing, appointments etc. example) Concept homes refused to acknowledge that I attended their meeting until I showed pictures of the contract I signed in their building. 

Issues like being "strongly recommended" a counter depth fridge because the door will hit the island, and not offering any counter depth fridges in the upgrades was ridiculous. 

Leg work for calling and communicating with others from Tamarack team was often placed on me the buyer. 

My house closing date was pushed back because design centre process took too long, when upon purchase I was told that if I met the instructed dates, the house would be available on time. I purchased the house with that promise, made every meeting on time, and still this was an issue. Design centre contracts had multiple mistakes and changes in them from what I had picked at the time of signing. If I was careless and just signed, my home would be completely different.

Overall communication was terrible, often I would be re-explaining or redoing a process multiple times to multiple people to get everyone on the same page myself. Home buying with Tamarack has unfortunately been a very painful process. No compensation, or solutions were found to many of my issues ex) I am now paying for a fridge that does not fit the unit. I will have to buy a new fridge somewhere else, only to gift or sell the one I am forcefully purchasing with Tamarack. Muskoka was looking to redesign my kitchen to accommodate at my financial expense because of the door issue. None of this was explained or mentioned before I had already signed.

Furthermore, despite these issues not being fixed yet. I am continued to be asked for more and more deposits.

Overall, I had originally planned to buy multiple investment homes in the new Findlay Creek area, but this home buying experience has truly made me consider going with other companies for my upcoming purchases.
It was problem free.

I would have liked to see the standard plumbing clearly illustrated in the design centre.  I still have no idea of the faucet that will be placed in my four bathroom sinks.  I will know when I move in.  The faucet was described, but a visual replica would have been appreciated.
Better understanding of deadlines/timelines for design/upgrades to be determined.

We were not entirely happy with the kitchen design process.  We felt that Gayle at Muskoka did not really present options or ideas, just tried to design a simple rectangle island and it took a lot of effort to get her to draw the island we envisioned.
provide construction updates when major tasks are completed.

Better communication between design centre, implications of timeline and impact on build schedule with head office.  In my case, my closing date was delayed without any indication that I had exceeded a milestone, thereby giving neither the design centre nor myself any opportunities to ensure that we had completed the final design within schedule.  In the end I believe things worked out well, but it indicated that some improvements could be made during the communication process.
Just a note, we did not need to go through the designing processes. Thus, we answered all 5s. Wish there was a N/A button.

I should be educated more about the difference between model home and the home that i am buying, like i missed to note that the side light is missing and door is full glass in new design which i over looked and later came as a surprise to me. For design centre, the person should be more knowledgable, like she missed to educate me that garage door is not part of interior door package, i upgraded all my indoor to smooth finish and came as a surprise during frame walk through.

The biggest thing that I would change in the design process is the kitchen manufacturer. It was extremely difficult and at times frustrating not being able to go into a local kitchen place and directly speak with reps.  I have used a local company when building my first house and it offered way more selection and restructuring based upon measurements.  I was able to get professional advice, I was expecting that when designing my kitchen with Tamarack, however this was not the case and it was just a series of unexplained emails between Muskoka and Tamarack. Your reps did as best they could with the situation however I still feel like I would have benefited more from walking into a local manufacturer and getting face to face time.
Muskoka rep was not very knowledgable or helpful.  The options catalogue should be online, with pictures, and with better descriptions.

Document possible/potential upgrades to homes, so people would know what to ask/upgrade. This would be extremely useful.

Mention pros and cons of not having or having certain features in the new home. Example hot water tank and this new device that is in place instead, which I've been told rent is more expensive and  shows some inconviniences.

we were very disappointed that the house was delayed. we had gone with Tamarack as a builder for their reputation of not delaying the build, so we were disappointed when the house was delayed.

When establishing a budget its crucisl to know estimayrs for bug ticket items.  I wasnt provided estimates for some items until a day before the last final meeting.  The estimate for my biggest item was one i continued to ask about since day 1 and nobody could assist with any form of an estimate.
have discounts for hitting specified dollar levels at the design centre. the more you spend the bigger the discount

I would educate her more than she is.  She must be better than this.  She should try to have knowledge of what she is selling.  She didn't give us a chance to read.  There is no solution.  You guys are getting the money and we end up with no solutions.  We are suffering.

For purachsers who have never been part of the building process before, it would help if there was a tutorial or optional meeting to become more familiar with the process and timelines for each stage of selections and building process. 1. give buyer catalog about different design option and price.

Ann was the first point of contact and was not knowledgeable and differed our questions completely.  We were however happy with the pricing and look of the homes and still purchased.  We had further administrative problems, missed/errors in paperwork on two separate occasions. Changes and confusion regarding scheduled appointments. Called to book something with us and then later realized they had pulled the wrong file after we had made daycare arrangements.  We feel that the administrative process was very disorganized and unprofessional.
Our design centre experience was the best part.  Christine was amazing to work with, very knowledgeable, personable and professional.
Note - I didn't have a blue print meeting.

Sale person must be more clear and specific about the models, and go through the details instead of calculatiing how much their comission will be on this house. I used to think that TAMARAk was a better compnay compare to other builder but I was obviously wrong.

Ensure upgrade sheets are updated as items in the design center did not adhere to the upgrade sheets (where items were listed as "included, $0.00", we were told they were not included and had a fee).

We had an appointment with the sales representative and waited over an hour for her to finish up with the clients beforehand even though we had an appointment. Do not book back to back appointments or adhere to committed schedule as per Tamarack's booking.
Offer more choices in the builders standard options selections.  Upgrades can add a lot of costs  in the already costly venture of buying a home.
We felt the design center could have been a better experience for new home buyers.  More help chosing designs and more one on one time with designers.

Our main issue is that the sales centre never properly communicated with the design centre what clients could and could not do until after designs were chosen. The design representatives should be well aware of changes in policy and design limitations. We would be told one thing by the design centre and then have that refuted by the sales centre later on, which meant our customization expectations weren't met. It was a headache to have to fight for the things we were told we could have. 
 
For instance, 1) we were initially told by the design centre that we could pay to have the ensuite shower tiled, but had that option revoked; 2) we wanted all standard plumbing but were told after we signed the upgrades list that our choice of double sinks in the ensuite bathroom would need sink upgrades; 3) we were told we could change out a full glass exterior door that isn't conducive to privacy for a windowless one, but were told by the sales centre that our contract clearly indicated that this wasn’t changeable. We understood that the selections listed in the contract were pre-installed because we were late to the party with our purchase, but that we could change them if we were willing to pay for it. 
 
We also felt that we had to be our own project manager for this experience, from the home theatre people to the cabinetry people. We signed multiple amendments to the final upgrades list because our specifications were always a bit off each time they were presented to us. This was unnecessarily stressful. We're still waiting on the last signed amendments with the final cost to send to our mortgage broker. These should have been signed by the builder and sent to us already, as our last signed amendment was sent May 16, 2017. 
 
Based on this experience, we're wary to recommend a new Tamarack home to others. It remains to be seen whether the quality of the build meets our expectations. We truly hope what we went through is the exception to the rule.  

We will say that, through it all, Morgan Champagne tried hard to ensure all our concerns were addressed, and answered every question we had promptly, whether by email or phone. I can't fault her for the miscommunication between all the different areas. We truly felt supported by her despite the various setbacks.

We would have liked to be given credits for items not used (carpet, etc). Also, although we spent a lot of money on upgrades, we would have spent a lot more if the costs passed on to us weren't so expensive (cost is more than triple than if we buy it ourselves; toilets, shower heads, etc).
more standard finishings in the models
Give more choices in the standard options

We are not impressed by Carolyn Hawkes, Design Coordinator. She was unprepared for our first meeting and did not provide us with enough information to make our selections. The design center was not ready and we had a difficult time going through our options. Carolyn did not show any urgency and took days to reply to our emails. Lastly, she did not forward us the pricing estimates promptly and we had to rush through at the very end to meet our deadline. In the whole process of buying a Tamarack Home, the design process was a complete disappointment.

The design centre staff were extremely friendly and welcoming however overall they seemed too busy.  Although our consultant was excellent, I didn't feel like she had the time to help with the choices as much as I would have liked, but overall it was a good experience just feel that there could have been more time allotted to the meetings.  

The kitchen design process was a little difficult and very rushed.  At times, I felt like I was a nuisance to the designer, but to give her the benifit of the doubt, she did seem to have a heavy load on her plate.

Sales rep was fantastic - knowledgeable, patient, professional, even under the handicap of having to explain our occupancy being delayed so often. However, one big negative for us was the excessive delay (8 months) between the down payment and Tamarack's obtaining of the building permit for our home, from the city. This was followed by two more notices of delay of occupancy of our home. From Design Centre selections to occupancy of our home will be approx. ONE YEAR!! And the notices of dalay made it very difficulot to offer our current home for sale with a firm occupancy date.

I think that we got in to this house a little late and they had already closed up the walls not allowing us to have pot lights. We were told when we purchased the home that it would not be a problem to later find out it was.

Also I marked '1' on the survey for walk through because we haven't moved in yet.
More time for design centre selection

it was really well organized.
staff was helpful and courteous.

The process is very streamlined and both Jaqueline & Carolyn are very knowledgeable. 

The only thing we would modify perhaps, is one step during the design centre process related to the kitchen. There were a few pages of 'upgrades' that seemed unnecessary i.e. asking if we wanted plastic utensil liners for our drawers or garbage bins under the sink. When you're purchasing a new home that is comparatively more expensive than other builders in the area (rightfully so), it seems odd to go through sheets containing multiple items priced in the $30-$100 range. While we felt no pressure whatsoever from the salesperson to purchase these items, that was the only time it actually felt like Tamarack was in the business of making a profit from their customers.
The design to have more available hours (evenings) we work during the day. The time they had on the door (saying open) they were closed.

If I could change anything about the process it would be not getting straight answers to questions that were posed.  When some people don't know answers to questions they should say they don't know, otherwise don't tell me that something is possible and then two weeks later tell me it's not.  I believe the house will be of good quality but the customer service from the sales reps to the design center to the site super needs a severe improvement for me To ever buy from or recommend Tamarak to anyone.
Sales centre process was perfect. For the design centre process, it was difficult to get a hold of the representatives over the phone and more clarification on items for upgrade.
If there is a minor change to be made, that was overlooked, it would be nice if Tamarack could accommodate such a change. (Ex: Adding an electrical outlet to the island)
The second design center meeting felt very rushed. I think we could have benefitted from a longer session.

1)We would like to suggest that any yearly changes to structure and offerings made by head office be made available at the beginning of the calendar year for homes purchased after January 1st.
    a. We purchased our home in January of 2015 and were given the upgrade      bonus that was applicable at that time. We went to the design centre in early March and were given a copy of the upgrade lists and respective costs. We did not start the design process until much later in the year (July) and once the process started there was significant confusion as to what options were standard and what were not. We were given the list of the 2015 standard lighting (which we liked) but that list was later rescinded because, according to head office, even though we had purchased in 2015 we had to choose from the 2014 lighting list (which we did not like). After several negotiations, in January of this year we were finally offered 5 lights from the 2015 list to be installed at no cost.
    b. The same option list switch occurred when we chose our granite; an upgrade to us but standard for houses bought later in 2015. This was resolved eventually to our satisfaction but it did cause some distress. In several instances, there was a remarkable increase in costs for our upgrades which put some items outside our upgrade overrun budget causing considerable disappointment. 
    c. There seemed to be a significant lag between head office and the sales/design centres as to what options were standard versus upgrades. 

2)We would like to suggest more flexibility in making minor design changes in town homes as well as single homes
    a.We asked several times to have a design modification made to remove a non supporting post at the steps from the foyer to the open concept kitchen family room area. We really, really do not want that post and even though we offered to pay the difference for the costs of the additional newel post and railing, there was no negotiation and were told that such modifications would only be granted in a single family home not a townhome. If it were a matter of simply making the change later on at our own costs, it would not be an issue but a change down the road would require matching stains for a new section of wood flooring and step nosing as well as replacing a section of the railing. It would have been much less work effort and cost to make this change while the home was under construction.

Our experience in the Sales Ctre has been wonderful but it is the negative experiences with the Design Ctre and the significant delay in construction at a time when interest rates were on the rise that has resulted in an unfavourable reference for Tamarack to our friends and family.
Nothing to change

When I asked about changing or adding some structural features, the answer was always no. For example: We wanted insulation between bedroom walls but they would not allow for that for a town-home.  
The roof vents: Tamarack only offers mushroom vents but every roofer in the city suggests the max-air flow vents. I am personally going to have to pay a roofer to put those in because I know the problems that the mushroom vents cause. It is ridiculous that I did not have the option to change. I'm not sure why Tamarack thinks they are above the what everyone in the industry recommends.
Dry core floor:  was not able to add a one in the basement
